images.copyright: Aerial view of a roundabout in Dhaka, Bangladesh (© Azim Khan Ronnie/Amazing Aerial Agency)
images.title: Dark night, city lights
images.caption: Dhaka, Bangladesh
images.desc: Cultural opulence, bustling economy and spirited locals—welcome to Dhaka in Bangladesh! This megacity on the Ganges Delta, home to over 10.2 million people, is one of the most densely populated cities on the planet. Once known as Jahangirnagar after ruling emperor Jahangir, Dhaka was the provincial capital of the Mughal Empire for 75 years in total. Dhaka has been nicknamed 'City of Mosques' because of the hundreds of elegant minarets that dot the city.

images.title: Getting lost in the mist
images.caption: World Rainforest Day
images.desc: Fresh air, lush foliage, rustling leaves and calls of thousands of species of animals and birds—welcome to the Amazon rainforest. Today, on World Rainforest Day, let's give a shout-out to this region. Covering over 5,500,000 square kilometres, this ecological treasure in South America extends its branches across nine nations—Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname and Venezuela.

og.title: World Rainforest Day

images.copyright: Interior exhibits of the Canadian Museum of History (© Inspired By Maps/Shutterstock)
images.title: Happy Indigenous Day!
images.caption: National Indigenous Peoples Day
images.desc: National Indigenous Peoples Day is observed on June 21 to honour the rich cultures, languages and traditions of First Nations, Inuit and Métis communities. It was established in 1996 to highlight Indigenous peoples' resilience, creativity and their imprints on the country's multicultural tapestry. On this day, communities come together to celebrate through music, dance, art and traditions.

og.title: National Indigenous Peoples Day

images.copyright: Kokino, an ancient megalithic observatory, North Macedonia (© stoimilov/Shutterstock)
images.title: Sunrise on the Solstice
images.caption: Summer solstice
images.desc: It's that time of year again—the daylight stretches long into the evening hours! This phenomenon, known as the summer solstice, occurs when one of the Earth's poles is most inclined toward the sun. Today's image features the Kokino megalithic observatory, which is part of the Kokino archaeological site in North Macedonia. It is believed that the Kokino observatory marked the position of the sun during summer and winter solstices, as well as the equinox, and consists of two platforms. A stone block on the upper platform of the observatory indicates the summer solstice sunrise direction when seen from a seat on the lower platform. So, when in North Macedonia, don't miss out on experiencing this ancient astronomical wonder!

og.title: Summer solstice
og.desc: It's that time of year again—the daylight stretches long into the evening hours! This phenomenon, known as the summer solstice, occurs when…

images.copyright: Reticulated giraffe mother greeting calf, Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, Kenya (© Sean Crane/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Spot-on connection
images.caption: Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, Kenya
images.desc: Giraffes have fascinated travellers from around the world for a long time. These animals were viewed as symbols of status and treasured as pets among royalty. Featured here are reticulated giraffes, found mostly in the Kenyan wild at the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, where they roam with poise under the vast African sky. Established in 1995, this sanctuary has become a haven for these gentle giants, distinguished by their vividly tessellated coats, and polygonal-shaped spots that extend onto the lower legs, tail and face. Unfortunately, only around 16,000 reticulated giraffes remain in the wild, less than half of the approximately 36,000 recorded in the 1980s. Nevertheless, recent years have observed a promising trend in northern Kenya, where populations are rebounding thanks to places like the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy. So, let's pledge to protect these creatures and their habitats.

og.title: Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, Kenya
og.desc: Giraffes have fascinated travellers from around the world for a long time. These animals were viewed as symbols of status and treasured as…

images.copyright: Lupine fields and church at sunrise, Snæfellsnes Peninsula, Iceland (© Matteo Colombo/Getty Images)
images.title: 'Lupin' into summer
images.caption: Lupine fields, Snæfellsnes, Iceland
images.desc: As spring gives way to summer in Iceland, the rugged landscape puts on a colourful parade. Lupines were introduced to Iceland in the 1940s for soil erosion control due to their roots' soil-binding properties. The plant flourishes in sandy and salty soils and propagates rapidly, painting the countryside with hues of purple, pink and blue. Although some consider lupine to be an invasive species that threatens native plants, its arrival is welcomed by locals and tourists as a cherished characteristic of the summer landscape. You can find lupine fields in various regions, including Reykjavík and near the Skógafoss waterfall. These flowers also line the road leading to the Hellissandur Church in the Snæfellsnes Peninsula, as seen in today's image.

og.title: Lupine fields, Snæfellsnes, Iceland

images.copyright: Green-crowned brilliant hummingbird with giant thistle, Cerro de la Muerte, Costa Rica (© adrian hepworth/Alamy)
images.title: Spread the pollen
images.caption: Pollinator Week
images.desc: Let's celebrate the small heroes who help plants flourish! It's Pollinator Week, celebrating the creatures which transport pollen to help plants reproduce. While some plants are self-pollinating, or pollinated by wind or water, the majority of them are fertilised with the help of bees, wasps, butterflies, moths, birds—like the green-crowned brilliant hummingbird in today's image—and even bats. The non-profit organisation Pollinator Partnership initiated Pollinator Week to raise awareness about the protection of these creatures. This celebration is now being joined by other programs and educational events around the country. Should we care? Absolutely! From fruits and veggies to nuts, chocolate or sugarcane, there are plenty of ingredients in our diet that are brought to us by pollinators.

og.title: Pollinator Week
og.desc: Let's celebrate the small heroes who help plants flourish! It's Pollinator Week, celebrating the creatures which transport pollen to help…

images.copyright: Red fox father and kit, Washington (© Chase Dekker/Minden Pictures)
images.title: This father won't be outfoxed
images.caption: Happy Father's Day!
images.desc: Today's all about the dads. Father's Day is the perfect time to celebrate everything they do for us, how they look after us, help us grow up and tell the best dad jokes. There are also great dads in the animal kingdom, like the foxy father seen in today's image. Female red foxes need to stay in their dens with their young after giving birth, so males spend their time going out to bring her food. When the pups are a little older, their father takes time to play with them, teaching them survival skills they'll need in later life, like hunting and scavenging. The foxes seen here are melanistic, a condition in animals that results in darker colouring.
